title: 1 Kings Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 11.

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 11:1, King Solomon loved many strange women from which of the following nations?
options: Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Zidonians, and Hittites
questions.correctAnswer: Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Zidonians, and Hittites
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:1 lists these specific nations as the origin of Solomon's strange women.

questions.question: How many wives and concubines did Solomon have according to 1 Kings 11:3?
questions.correctAnswer: 700 wives and 300 concubines
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:3 states Solomon had seven hundred wives and three hundred concubines.

questions.question: True or False: Solomon's heart was perfect with the LORD his God as was the heart of David his father, according to 1 Kings 11:4.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:4 explains that Solomon's heart was not perfect with the LORD as was David's heart.

questions.question: Which goddess did Solomon go after, as mentioned in 1 Kings 11:5?
options: Ashtoreth, the goddess of the Zidonians
Astarte, the goddess of the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Ashtoreth, the goddess of the Zidonians
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:5 states Solomon went after Ashtoreth, the goddess of the Zidonians.

questions.question: What action did Solomon take in 1 Kings 11:7 regarding Chemosh and Molech?
options: Built a high place for Chemosh and Molech
Destroyed the idols of Chemosh and Molech
Wrote laws against worshipping Chemosh and Molech
Sent ambassadors to Chemosh and Molech's priests
questions.correctAnswer: Built a high place for Chemosh and Molech
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:7 says Solomon built a high place for Chemosh and Molech.

questions.question: Who was stirred up by the LORD as an adversary to Solomon according to 1 Kings 11:14?
questions.correctAnswer: Hadad the Edomite
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:14 shows the LORD stirred up Hadad the Edomite as an adversary to Solomon.

questions.question: True or False: Hadad was given a house, victuals, and land in Egypt by Pharaoh as stated in 1 Kings 11:18.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:18 records that Pharaoh gave Hadad a house, food, and land in Egypt.

questions.question: Who was the sister of Tahpenes that Pharaoh gave to Hadad as a wife, according to 1 Kings 11:19?
options: The sister of Tahpenes the queen
questions.correctAnswer: The sister of Tahpenes the queen
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:19 states Pharaoh gave Hadad the sister of Tahpenes as a wife.

questions.question: What did the prophet Ahijah do to his new garment when he met Jeroboam, as described in 1 Kings 11:30?
questions.correctAnswer: Rent it in twelve pieces
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:30 says Ahijah rent his new garment into twelve pieces when he met Jeroboam.

questions.question: How many pieces of the garment did Ahijah tell Jeroboam to take, according to 1 Kings 11:31?
questions.correctAnswer: Ten pieces
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:31 records Ahijah told Jeroboam to take ten pieces representing ten tribes.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Kings 11:33, the people worshipped the gods Chemosh, Milcom, and Ashtoreth and did not walk in God's ways.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:33 confirms that the people worshipped these gods and forsook God's ways.

questions.question: Who did Solomon seek to kill, causing that person to flee to Egypt, as stated in 1 Kings 11:40?
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:40 mentions Solomon sought to kill Jeroboam, who fled to Egypt.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'And Solomon slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of _________ his father.' (1 Kings 11:43)
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:43 states Solomon was buried in the city of David his father.

questions.question: How many years did Solomon reign over all Israel according to 1 Kings 11:42?
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:42 states Solomon reigned for forty years.

questions.question: Who became captain over a band and reigned in Damascus, opposing Israel during Solomon's reign, according to 1 Kings 11:23-25?
questions.correctAnswer: Rezon the son of Eliadah
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:23-25 states Rezon became captain and reigned over Damascus as adversary to Israel.

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 11 teach us about the importance of obedience to God's commands in marriage?
options: Solomon's many foreign wives led him away from God, showing disobedience harms faith
Solomon's wives strengthened his faith and obedience to God
God encouraged Solomon to marry many wives for political alliances
Solomon's wives had no impact on his relationship with God
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon's many foreign wives led him away from God, showing disobedience harms faith
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:1-4 explains Solomon loved many foreign wives who turned his heart after other gods, showing disobedience to God's commands about marriage led him away from faith. This teaches that obedience in marriage is vital for spiritual health.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with temptation to compromise their faith for worldly relationships. Based on 1 Kings 11, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Remaining fully devoted to God prevents the heart from turning to other gods
It is acceptable to follow other gods if pressured by relationships
Compromise with worldly influences strengthens faith
God accepts divided loyalties as normal
questions.correctAnswer: Remaining fully devoted to God prevents the heart from turning to other gods
questions.explanation: Verses 11:2-4 and 11:9-10 emphasize Solomon's heart was turned from the LORD because he did not keep God's command to avoid foreign gods. This teaches the importance of full devotion to God to resist temptation.

questions.question: What practical lesson about spiritual discipline is taught by Solomon’s turning away from God in his old age?
options: Continuous spiritual discipline is necessary to keep a perfect heart with God
Spiritual discipline is only important in youth
Spiritual discipline is not required if one was faithful earlier
questions.correctAnswer: Continuous spiritual discipline is necessary to keep a perfect heart with God
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:4 states Solomon’s heart was not perfect with God in old age because his wives turned him after other gods. This shows the need for ongoing spiritual discipline throughout life.

questions.question: How can 1 Kings 11 guide a believer who is struggling with the consequences of disobedience?
options: God may discipline but remains faithful to His covenant and promises
Disobedience leads to immediate total rejection by God
There is no hope after disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: God may discipline but remains faithful to His covenant and promises
questions.explanation: Verses 11:11-13 and 11:34 explain that God was angry with Solomon and would take the kingdom from him but not during his lifetime, showing God’s discipline is tempered by His covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 11 teach about God’s justice and mercy in leadership?
options: God punishes leaders for disobedience but maintains mercy for David’s lineage
God disregards disobedience if the leader is wise
God rewards disobedience with long reigns
Leaders are exempt from God's judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God punishes leaders for disobedience but maintains mercy for David’s lineage
questions.explanation: Verses 11:11-13 and 11:34-36 reveal God’s justice in punishing Solomon but mercy in preserving David’s family line, demonstrating both justice and grace in leadership.

questions.question: How does the story of Jeroboam in 1 Kings 11 teach about integrity and ambition in service to God?
options: God raises leaders who walk in His ways and keep His commandments
Ambition without obedience will always be rewarded
Service to God requires no personal integrity
Leaders can succeed regardless of their spiritual walk
questions.correctAnswer: God raises leaders who walk in His ways and keep His commandments
questions.explanation: Verses 11:28-38 show Jeroboam was industrious and God promised him a kingdom if he obeyed commandments, teaching leadership requires integrity and obedience.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Kings 11, Solomon’s heart was perfect with the LORD his God, just like David his father.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:4 clearly states Solomon’s heart was not perfect with the LORD his God as was the heart of David, showing Solomon’s failure in full obedience.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD appeared to Solomon twice and commanded him not to follow other gods, but Solomon obeyed fully.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 11:9-10 say the LORD appeared twice and commanded Solomon not to follow other gods, but Solomon did not keep the command, showing disobedience.

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 11, what is a consequence of turning away from God to worship other gods?
options: God's anger and judgment, including dividing the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: God's anger and judgment, including dividing the kingdom
questions.explanation: Verses 11:9-14 and 11:26-40 describe God’s anger with Solomon and His decision to rend the kingdom as judgment for idolatry.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 11 illustrate the importance of faithfulness in God's service for a believer’s work ethic?
options: Jeroboam was made ruler because he was industrious and faithful
Faithfulness is unrelated to leadership or work
God rewards only wisdom, not faithfulness
Hard work alone guarantees God's blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam was made ruler because he was industrious and faithful
questions.explanation: Verse 11:28 shows Solomon noticed Jeroboam’s industriousness and made him ruler, indicating faithfulness and diligence are valued in God’s service.

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to compromise their devotion for political or social gain. What does 1 Kings 11 teach about such compromises?
options: Compromise leads to turning away from God and eventual judgment
God blesses those who compromise for peace
Political gain is more important than faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Compromise leads to turning away from God and eventual judgment
questions.explanation: Solomon’s alliances and foreign marriages led him to idolatry (11:1-8) and God’s judgment (11:9-11), showing compromises harm spiritual devotion.

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 11 teach about God’s faithfulness even when His people fail?
options: God preserves a remnant and fulfills His promises for David's sake
God abandons His people completely after failure
God forgets His covenant in anger
questions.correctAnswer: God preserves a remnant and fulfills His promises for David's sake
questions.explanation: Verses 11:12-13 and 11:34-36 show God’s mercy in preserving one tribe and David’s lineage despite Solomon’s failure.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 1 Kings 11, Solomon's wives turned away his heart after __________, and his heart was not perfect with the LORD as was the heart of David his father.
questions.correctAnswer: other gods
questions.explanation: Verse 11:4 clearly states Solomon's wives turned away his heart after other gods, resulting in an imperfect heart before the LORD.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 11 provide guidance on dealing with temptation in family life?
options: Guard your heart and avoid influences that lead you away from God
Family influences have no impact on faith
It's acceptable to blend worship practices
Temptation is unavoidable and cannot be resisted
questions.correctAnswer: Guard your heart and avoid influences that lead you away from God
questions.explanation: Solomon’s heart was turned away by his wives worshipping other gods (11:1-8), teaching the importance of guarding the heart against ungodly influences in family.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and divine guidance can be drawn from Jeroboam’s encounter with the prophet Ahijah?
options: Obedience to God’s commands is required to receive His blessings
Prophecy guarantees success regardless of behavior
Divine guidance is optional for leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s commands is required to receive His blessings
questions.explanation: Ahijah’s prophecy (11:29-38) includes a condition that Jeroboam must obey God’s commands to reign and have a sure house, emphasizing humility and obedience.

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 11.

questions.question: Which foreign nations' women did Solomon love, despite the LORD's command to Israel?
options: Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Zidonians, and Hittites
Philistines, Egyptians, Canaanites, Amorites, and Hittites
Babylonians, Assyrians, Moabites, Hittites, and Edomites
Ammonites, Moabites, Egyptians, Syrians, and Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Zidonians, and Hittites
questions.explanation: According to 1 Kings 11:1, Solomon loved many strange women, including those from the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Zidonians, and Hittites, which the LORD had warned against.

questions.question: What was the LORD's specific warning to Israel about intermarrying with foreign nations as stated in 1 Kings 11?
options: They will turn away your heart after their gods
They will bring famine to your land
They will wage war against you
questions.correctAnswer: They will turn away your heart after their gods
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:2 shows God's warning that the foreign nations would cause Israel to turn their hearts after other gods, leading them away from Jehovah.

questions.question: How many wives and concubines did Solomon have according to 1 Kings 11?
questions.correctAnswer: 700 wives and 300 concubines
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:3 states Solomon had 700 wives and 300 concubines, illustrating his extensive marriages which contributed to his heart turning away.

questions.question: Which goddess of the Zidonians did Solomon go after, as mentioned in 1 Kings 11?
questions.correctAnswer: Ashtoreth
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:5 specifically mentions Solomon went after Ashtoreth, the goddess of the Zidonians, indicating his idolatry influenced by foreign wives.

questions.question: What action did Solomon take that was considered evil in the sight of the LORD according to 1 Kings 11?
options: He built high places for Chemosh and Molech
He allied with Egypt against Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He built high places for Chemosh and Molech
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:7 says Solomon built high places for Chemosh and Molech, gods of Moab and Ammon, which was evil in the LORD's eyes.

questions.question: What was the LORD's response to Solomon's heart turning away and his idolatry?
options: The LORD was angry and declared He would rend the kingdom from Solomon
The LORD blessed Solomon with more wealth
The LORD sent a famine on the land
The LORD allowed him to reign peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD was angry and declared He would rend the kingdom from Solomon
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:9-11 shows the LORD's anger and the decision to take the kingdom away from Solomon due to his disobedience.

questions.question: Why did God delay taking the kingdom from Solomon during his lifetime?
options: Due to the prayers of the priests
questions.correctAnswer: For David's sake, his father
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:12 explains that God delayed the judgment for David's sake, showing divine mercy out of respect for David's faithfulness.

questions.question: Who was Hadad the Edomite, and what role did he play as an adversary to Solomon?
options: A descendant of the king's seed in Edom stirred up by God to oppose Solomon
A Philistine warrior allied with Egypt
A Moabite king who invaded Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A descendant of the king's seed in Edom stirred up by God to oppose Solomon
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:14 describes Hadad as an adversary raised by God against Solomon, a member of Edomite royal lineage.

questions.question: What significant event in Edom's history is connected to Hadad's flight to Egypt?
options: Joab's massacre of Edomite males during David's reign
The fall of Edom to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Joab's massacre of Edomite males during David's reign
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:15-16 recounts Joab's six-month campaign killing Edomite males, which caused Hadad to flee as a child to Egypt.

questions.question: How did Pharaoh treat Hadad when he fled to Egypt, according to 1 Kings 11?
options: He gave Hadad a house, food, land, and a wife
He sent Hadad back to Edom
questions.correctAnswer: He gave Hadad a house, food, land, and a wife
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:18-19 states Pharaoh showed favor to Hadad by providing him a house, provisions, land, and marrying him to the sister of Pharaoh's wife.

questions.question: Who was Rezon son of Eliadah, and what was his significance in 1 Kings 11?
options: Another adversary to Israel raised by God, who reigned over Damascus
A foreign merchant allied with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Another adversary to Israel raised by God, who reigned over Damascus
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:23-25 describes Rezon as an adversary raised by God who ruled in Damascus and opposed Israel during Solomon's reign.

questions.question: What role did Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, play during Solomon's reign?
options: He was a mighty man of valor who rebelled against Solomon
He was a prophet supporting Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: He was a mighty man of valor who rebelled against Solomon
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:26 and 28 identify Jeroboam as a strong man who lifted his hand against Solomon and was made ruler over the house of Joseph.

questions.question: How did the prophet Ahijah signify to Jeroboam the division of the kingdom?
options: By tearing a new garment into twelve pieces and giving ten to Jeroboam
By giving him a scroll of prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: By tearing a new garment into twelve pieces and giving ten to Jeroboam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:29-31 describes Ahijah tearing his garment into twelve pieces and giving ten to Jeroboam, symbolizing the ten tribes he would rule.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The LORD promised to give Jeroboam ten tribes, but Solomon's son would retain ______ for David's sake.
questions.correctAnswer: one tribe
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:13 and 32 explain that Solomon's son would keep one tribe as a light for David's sake while the other ten would be given to Jeroboam.

questions.question: True or False: Solomon's heart was perfect with the LORD, just as David's was.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:4 explicitly states Solomon's heart was not perfect with the LORD as David's heart was, because his wives turned him to other gods.

questions.question: What was the ultimate fate of Solomon as recorded at the end of this chapter?
options: He died and was buried in the city of David, succeeded by his son Rehoboam
He abdicated and lived in seclusion
questions.correctAnswer: He died and was buried in the city of David, succeeded by his son Rehoboam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:43 notes Solomon 'slept with his fathers' and was buried in the city of David, with Rehoboam reigning after him.

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary reason for God's anger towards Solomon according to 1 Kings 11?
options: Solomon's heart turned away from the LORD, worshipping other gods
Solomon failed to build the temple properly
Solomon did not have enough wives
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon's heart turned away from the LORD, worshipping other gods
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:9-10 states that the LORD was angry because Solomon's heart turned from God and he did not keep God's commandments, consistent with Deuteronomy 6:15 and Jeremiah 7:23 which emphasize exclusive devotion to God.

questions.question: How many wives and concubines did Solomon have according to 1 Kings 11?
questions.correctAnswer: 700 wives and 300 concubines
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:3 reports Solomon had 700 wives and 300 concubines, showing his extensive alliances, which led to idolatry, echoing warnings in Deuteronomy 17:17 against multiplying wives.

questions.question: Which gods did Solomon worship because of his wives, as stated in 1 Kings 11?
questions.correctAnswer: Ashtoreth, Milcom, Chemosh, Molech
questions.explanation: Verses 5-7 specify Solomon worshipped Ashtoreth (Zidonians), Milcom (Ammonites), Chemosh (Moabites), and Molech (Ammonites), highlighting idolatry forbidden in Exodus 20:3-5 and 1 Corinthians 10:14.

questions.question: What was the consequence God pronounced for Solomon's disobedience?
options: The kingdom would be torn from Solomon and given to his servant
Solomon would lose his wisdom but keep the kingdom
Solomon would be exiled to Egypt
His sons would be priests instead of kings
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom would be torn from Solomon and given to his servant
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:11 declares God would rend the kingdom from Solomon and give it to his servant, signifying divine judgment, paralleling Deuteronomy 28:36 about covenant disobedience consequences.

questions.question: Despite the judgment, what did God promise regarding Solomon's kingdom during his lifetime?
options: God would not take the kingdom during Solomon's lifetime for David's sake
God would immediately remove the kingdom from Solomon
Solomon would never have a son to succeed him
The kingdom would be divided before Solomon's death
questions.correctAnswer: God would not take the kingdom during Solomon's lifetime for David's sake
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:12 affirms God’s mercy to Solomon by preserving the kingdom during his life because of David, underscoring God's faithfulness to covenant promises as in 2 Samuel 7:12-16.

questions.question: Who was the adversary God raised against Solomon from Edom?
options: Joab the captain of the host
questions.correctAnswer: Hadad the Edomite
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:14 introduces Hadad the Edomite as an adversary stirred up by God, illustrating divine discipline, comparable to the adversaries raised against Israel in Judges 2:14.

questions.question: What role did Jeroboam play in Solomon's reign before his rebellion?
options: Ruler over the house of Joseph and a mighty man of valor
questions.correctAnswer: Ruler over the house of Joseph and a mighty man of valor
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:28 states Jeroboam was made ruler over the house of Joseph due to his industriousness, highlighting the rise of significant leaders within Israel, paralleling Joseph's leadership role in Genesis 41.

questions.question: What symbolic act did the prophet Ahijah perform when he met Jeroboam?
options: He tore a new garment into twelve pieces
He wrote a scroll of judgment
He built an altar for sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: He tore a new garment into twelve pieces
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:30 describes Ahijah tearing his garment into twelve pieces to symbolize the division of the kingdom, an act conveying prophetic authority similar to prophetic signs in Ezekiel 4:1-3.

questions.question: How many tribes did God promise to give Jeroboam?
questions.correctAnswer: Ten tribes
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:31 specifies that Jeroboam would receive ten tribes, reflecting the future divided kingdom, consistent with the historical split described in 2 Chronicles 10.

questions.question: Why would God not take the entire kingdom away from Solomon's son according to 1 Kings 11?
options: For David's sake and Jerusalem's sake
questions.correctAnswer: For David's sake and Jerusalem's sake
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:32-34 indicates God retained one tribe for David and Jerusalem's sake, showing God’s covenant faithfulness, paralleling God's promises in 2 Samuel 7 and Psalm 89.

questions.question: What is the condition given to Jeroboam to ensure God’s blessing and building a sure house for him?
options: He must walk in God's ways and keep His statutes and commandments
He must defeat all enemies of Israel
He must marry into Solomon's family
He must build a temple like Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: He must walk in God's ways and keep His statutes and commandments
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 11:38 states that obedience to God's commands would ensure God's presence and establishment of Jeroboam’s house, reflecting covenantal blessings as in Deuteronomy 28.

questions.question: What does the chapter reveal about the nature of God's justice and mercy?
options: God judges sin but preserves His covenant promises
God ignores disobedience for political reasons
God only blesses the righteous kings
questions.correctAnswer: God judges sin but preserves His covenant promises
questions.explanation: Throughout 1 Kings 11 (verses 11-12, 34-36), God disciplines Solomon’s house by division but spares part of the kingdom for David's sake, showing both justice and mercy, consistent with Exodus 34:6-7 and Psalm 103:8-12.

questions.question: What does Solomon's turning to other gods teach about human susceptibility to sin?
options: Even the wisest and most blessed can fall into idolatry
Only unwise leaders fall into sin
Sin is impossible for chosen kings
Idolatry is acceptable with foreign alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Even the wisest and most blessed can fall into idolatry
questions.explanation: Solomon’s fall (1 Kings 11:4-6) demonstrates human weakness and the danger of compromising God’s commands, echoing Romans 3:23 and James 1:14-15 on universal susceptibility to sin.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 11 contribute to the biblical doctrine of the Davidic covenant?
options: It shows God's unconditional commitment to David's line despite Solomon's failures
It proves that the covenant is conditional and can be revoked permanently
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God's unconditional commitment to David's line despite Solomon's failures
questions.explanation: Verses 12, 34-36 show God’s faithfulness to David’s covenant, preserving a tribe and promising a lasting dynasty, reflecting promises in 2 Samuel 7:16 and Luke 1:32-33.

questions.question: What theological theme regarding divine sovereignty is demonstrated by God raising adversaries against Solomon?
options: God sovereignly uses enemies to discipline and fulfill His purposes
God loses control when kings sin
God punishes only through natural disasters
God abandons His people when they sin
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly uses enemies to discipline and fulfill His purposes
questions.explanation: God stirring up Hadad and Rezon (1 Kings 11:14, 23) illustrates divine control over history and judgment, consistent with Isaiah 10:5-7 and Romans 8:28.

questions.question: What messianic implication can be drawn from God’s promise to keep one tribe for David's son?
options: God preserves the Davidic line culminating in the Messiah
The Messiah would come from the northern tribes
The kingdom would never be restored
The Messiah would be a foreign king
questions.correctAnswer: God preserves the Davidic line culminating in the Messiah
questions.explanation: The promise of one tribe for David’s son (1 Kings 11:32-36) points to the enduring Davidic covenant fulfilled in Christ, as affirmed in Isaiah 9:7 and Matthew 1:1.
